div.p: 1. October— Wednesday—

No relief— I received an invitation from Dr. Francis Parkman to dine with him and the Trustees of the Massachusetts Humane Society, next Friday which invitation, with the advice of Dr. Woodward I declined— Dr. Parkman sent me also a Pamphlet of 96. pages being a History of the Humane Society of Massachusetts, with a list of Premiums awarded by their Trustees and extracts from their Correspondents which I read, but upon which or upon any thing else that I read I have no power to write or indeed to make any useful remarks— I had also received invitations, to attend the Horticultural Festival on the 19th. of last month and the triannual festival of the Massachusetts Charitable Mechanic Association— I not only omitted to attend them, but even to answer the invitations— Intending to give my attendance till the days came, then finding myself too much indisposed to go—
2d. October— Thursday—

I continue to rise, after nearly sleepless nights between Four and five o’clock in the morning, and to go through my usual process of washing and Horse-hair friction, but cease from my heretofore customary exercise of digging in the Garden and Nursery and of walking up the Hill to my Son’s House to Hail the rising Sun— I received from Mr. Frye at Washington some enquiries concerning a person named James Ross in the year 1778. and another at a later date by the name of Benjamin Dudley. I answered by my proxy, my Grandaughter Mary Louisa Mr. Frye’s Letter, but could give him no information of the persons concerning whom, he enquired— I received also an invitation from Mr Charles King to be his guest with my family at the time of the proposed Celebration at Elizabeth-Town, next November, which I shall not be able to attend, and therefore declined Mr. King’s invitation— I rode out this afternoon in the Carriage with Mrs. Charles, Miss Cutts and my Grandaughter, and on returning stopt for a few minutes
at my Son’s House— He and his wife spend the evening here— I took again a Pill before going to bed, by direction of Dr. Woodward
3d. October— Friday

I rose this morning between 6. and 7. o’clock, intermitted all my usual exercises, and took again the medicine prescribed by Dr. Woodward— I answered the Letter of the Revd. Nicholas Murray of Elizabeth-Town of the 18th. last month and informed him of my inability to attend the Celebration in honour of the memory of the Revd. James Caldwell to take place on the 24th. of November next— I rode to Milton and Dorchester, with Miss Cutts and my Grandaughter before dinner— Mrs. Charles and Mary-Louisa went to Boston after dinner, and returned, in the evening, with my Grandaughter Louisa Catharine, from Mrs. Charles Sedgwick school in Lenox— Where a vacation of a month has commenced— I took this evening before going to bed a warm bath—
4th. October— Saturday—

Rose at five o’clock— Visit from Dr. Woodward with little or no change in the state of my health— Morning visits also from the Revd. William—Dr. Lunt and from Isaac-Hull Adams— My way of life leaves nothing more worth recording A warm bath at night, before going to bed— And a cup of Valerian Tea—
5th. October— Sunday— 1845—

Rose between five and six o’clock, and performed my usual ablutions and frictions, attended Public Worship, morning and afternoon— Mr. Lunt administered the Communion.— For his morning Sermon, he gave out two texts, one from Isaiah 55–4—“Behold I have given him for a witness to the people, a Leader and Commander to the people”— and the other from Revelation 1–5— “Jesus Christ who is the faithful witness”— The text of his afternoon Discourse was Galatians 6.10. “As we have therefore opportunity let us do good unto all men especially unto them who are of the household of Faith.” These were both excellent Sermons— There was rain a great part of the day and we rode to and from Meeting morning and afternoon—

Cold, rainy, and gloomy day.— I executed a Deed of Pew No 16. in the Stone Temple, in the gallery, to George Tyler
Bigelow of Boston— Warm bath at night before going to bed—

p.hi: Rose at 6. o’clock.— Did not make my own fire. Draught of Medicine prescribed by D
Woodward— Settled my account with the Quincy Stone Bank— Received from my Son a Check on the Merchants Branch Boston for 500: dollars— Afternoon ride with Miss Smith, M

Charles F. Adams and Miss Cutts— Call from John M. Brown—and Lewis Hayden; coloured men from Detroit Michigan, came to solicit contributions for a coloured Methodist School at Detroit of which John M. Brown is the Pastor and also teacher of a School for coloured children— The late Pres—

div.p: Bigelow of Boston— Warm bath at night before going to bed—
7— October 1845— Tuesday—

Rose at 6 o’clock— Did not make my own fire— Draught of Medicine prescribed by Dr. Woodward— Settled my account with the Quincy Stone Bank— Received from my Son a Check on the Merchants Bank, Boston for five-hundred dollars— Afternoon ride with Miss Cutts Mrs. Charles F. Adams, and Miss Smith— Call from John M. Brown and Lewis Hayden, coloured men, from Detroit, Michigan, came to solicit contributions for a coloured Methodist Church at Detroit of which John M Brown is the Pastor and also the teacher of a School for coloured children— The late President of Harvard University Josiah Quincy came to attend the Meeting of the Supervisors of the Temple and School Fund, which had been notified to him, by my Son, the Secretary of the Body— We had been under the necessity of postponing this Meeting to an indefinite time, But Mr. Quincy had not received notice of this postponement— The Meeting therefore failed— My Son and his wife passed the evening here—
8. October. 1845— Wednesday—

I deposited in the Quincy Stone Bank, a Check on the Merchants Bank, Boston for five hundred dollars, given me yesterday by my Son and drew a Check of One hundred dollars of the Bills of the Bank— I went in to Boston, with my Son, Miss Cutts, and my Grandaughter Louisa Catherine— I called twice upon Dr. Jacob Bigelow, and found him, at last, at home— In the interval I called upon the Late United States, District Judge—John Davis and returned to him, a Pamphlet of Astronomical Lectures, by Mr. Arago, and Dr. Lardner, which I had borrowed last Spring— I then went to my Son’s Office— And
then went to Mr. Robert C. Waterston’s House, No. 37. Temple Street, neither he or Mrs. Waterston were at home— And I returned two Volumes of Mrs. Jameson’s writings, which Mrs. Waterston lately lent me at Quincy— I called at the new residence of the late President Quincy near the State House, and saw Mrs. Quincy and the family. Mr. Quincy himself being out— I met at the door, Mrs. Isaac. P. Davis and in the House Mr. Waterston’s father— I thence returned to Dr. Bigelow’s and found him at home— I took his advice and prescriptions upon the state of my health The Carriage called for me there, and took up Miss Cutts and Louis Catharine, at Dr. Frothingham, and returned home, to Quincy to dine— A young man by the name of Alfred Richardson Glover of Milton was here this afternoon, very desirous of obtaining a warrant of Cadet at the Military Academy at West-Point— He brought with him, a Certificate, of good conduct, from his School Teacher— I told him if he would address an application to the Secretary of War soliciting the appointment, I would readily forward it for him, with his certificate from his Teacher— The present Cadet from the Eight Congressional District of Massachusetts, is to finish his course next June. There will then be a vacancy of a Cadet to be filled—from this District, and I told Mr. Glover that there are already several names of Candidates registered in the War Department for that appointment—with strong Certificates and recommendations— He said that the printed regulations of the War Department expressly declared that in the appointment of Cadets no regard is paid to priority of application— I said that however that might be, the practise is to allow the Representative, in Congress, for the District to nominate the Candidate and to appoint the person nominated by him—and if I should be called to make the nomination, between Candidates of equal claims in other respects I should not think it right to disregard all together priority of application— He thanked me for the offer to forward his application and said he would avail himself of it— Mrs. Charles spent the evening with us, and my Son came in, for half an hour from Mr. Beals—

I woke before the clock struck three, lay sleepless till five, then rose, and returned immediately to bed, and lay till Six when I rose for the day— Immediately after breakfast, A Mr. Ruggles, of Milton, and a person by the name of Adams, from Topsfield, in the County of Essex, paid me a visit, not of business, but of curiosity— Mr Adams, is not of the descent from the Patriarch Henry, but of a family long settled in the County of Essex— Dr. Woodward was here before dinner, and
advised and prescribed— I received this morning “The American Review,” for October— My Son and his wife spent the evening with us—

Awake to hear the clock strike four, and rose at half past five— Rainy morning, dull and gloomy day— Received a Letter from Seth Chandler, dated 6th. October instt. at Shirley— Requesting a Copy of my address to the Phi Beta Kappa Society at Cambridge delivered on the fifth of September 1788— He says it was printed, which I did not know, or have forgotten— I find my-self very feeble, but with the aid of my Grandaughter, found some occupation, in commencing to put my affairs, in order— My Letter—of the 6th. instt. to E. H. Blatchford of New-York, is published in the Boston Atlas and Courier of this day— Rainy day and evening which prevented Mrs. Charles from coming down—

Rose at four o’clock. and again at six— Exercise abridged, by the foulness of the weather— Received a Letter from John Pixley Burgett, dated at Utica New-York on the 8th. instt. requesting a Copy of the Oration on the Life and Character of Lafayette—delivered before the Congress of the United States on the 31st. of December 1834— This Letter was answered and a Copy of the Oration sent— A Letter was also written to C. Edwards Lester, New-York—thanking him for his Dedication of his translation of the work of Ansaldo Ceba entitled—“The Citizen of a Republic.” As Mr. Lester has requested my opinion of this Book I have undertaken to read it. A task of no ordinary burden, in my present condition—

Continuance of warm, showery, sultry weather— Rode to and from Meeting—morning and afternoon— Mr. Lunt preached both parts of the day—to very thin auditory—his text of the morning discourse was Titus 2.12. “Teaching us, that denying ungodliness and worldly lusts we should live soberly, righteously and godly in this present world”— He divided his Discourse into three classes of duties, embracing the whole duty of Man upon earth—and remarked that the precept to live soberly comprises all the duties of Man to himself that the command to Live righteously included all the duties of Man to his fellow-creatures and that of living Godly, all his duties to his Creator— The text of his afternoon Sermon was 2. Peter 1.7. “And, to Godliness brotherly kindness; and to brotherly kindness charity”—
Mr. Lunt’s Sermons were excellent— I went up to the Hill to my Sons house about sunset— My Son and his wife spent the later part of the evening here

Change of weather—from warm to cool, and from moist to dry— Mr. Samuel T. Armstrong of Boston, and his wife are going to Europe—and propose to embark in the Steamer Cambria to depart on the 16. of this month— Mr. Armstrong in a Letter of the 27. last month gave me notice of this intention, the object of which is the restoration, of his health and for pleasure and instruction, he proposes to visit many parts of Europe and to be absent a year or more— He intimates in his Letter a wish that I would furnish him with Letters of introduction and I accordingly wrote this day, by my proxy, Letters recommendating of him and his Lady, to Louis Mc’Lane—Minister of the United States to Great Britain—to William R. King—Minister to France, to Robert Walsh, Consul at Paris, and to George Joy of No 19. John street Pentonville London— I made a pacquet of these four Letters with one to Mr. Armstrong and sent them by the mail to him at Boston— I received this day from my old friend Christopher Hughes, three Copies of a small printed pamphlet containing the Narrative of the loss of the Ship Poland, by Miss Margaret S. Hughes his daughter who was a passenger in that luckless vessel—together with a Letter from Mr. Hughes himself to Joseph R. Ingersoll—and one or two other Letters published by Mr. Hughes and Dedicated to me— Besides two Letters requesting Autographs, such as I never answer. I received also from Samuel E. Sewall, Esqr. standing Candidate for the office of Governor for this Commonwealth of the so called Liberty party abolition Birney Party, and Chairman of the Great Convention of the friends of Freedom in the Eastern and Middle States held at Boston on the first three days of this month—a printed circular dated 10. Court Street Boston Oct 10. 1845. stating as the result of that Convention that they came to the conclusion that the Texas question is not yet settled and that her admission as a Slave state may be defeated, that if National infamy and ruin are strong enough to create a necessity it must be defeated, and then devising in their wisdom how it shall be defeated— The Liberty Abolition Birney constitute perhaps one Man in twenty of the Commonwealth of Massachusetts— They profess many good principles and practise some others.— I was ernestly invited to attend their Great Convention, but had the state of my health permitted could have
done no good, by my attendance— Alteri seculo—is the motto for the glory of the Commonwealth of Massachusetts on the day when she shall take an effective lead in breaking the Chains of the oppressed throughout the Earth That day is reserved for a future generation— Lastly there came this day postmarked from the American Philosophical Society at Philadelphia a printed pamphlet in quarto entitled Account of the Northumberland equatorial and Dome attached to the Cambridge Observatory (England) by G. B. Airy M.A. Astronomer royal late Plumian Professor in the University of Cambridge—with a paper pasted on the inside of the cover marking it, as presented it by the Duke of Northumberland to the Hon John Quincy Adams—and a printed notice requesting that acknowledgment of the receipt of this Copy of the description of the Northumberland equatoreal and Dome may be sent to Mr. Airy, Royal Observatory Greenwich— Dated at Greenwich 19. February 1845— I rode round the Braintree square this afternoon with my wife and Mrs. Charles—and we took Tea, and spent the evening with Elizabeth. C. Adams.

Rose at four oclock and five— There was a white frost in the night and about Sunrise I took a walk of half an hour for exercise— I received this morning an invitation from B. B. Noyes. G. N. Sykes. and Jas. O. H. Perry a Committee of the inhabitants of Bristol— R.I. to deliver a Lecture before them in the course of the present Autumn— And a Letter from John Eden dated Northampton 11. Octr. instt. containing a quisical reference to the third Latin Elegy of Milton My wife and Mrs. Charles F. Adams went to Boston this morning and returned home to dine— Which deprived us of the usual visit of Mrs. Charles in the evening— I walked up to the Hill at Sunset, and employed much of the day in writing a Letter of introduction for Mr. Armstrong to G. B. Airy Esqr. the English Royal Astronomer, in which I acknowledged the receipt of his Account of the Northumberland Equatoreal and Dome. This Letter I enclosed to Mr. Armstrong and sent it by the Mail—

Rose at four and at a quarter before six o’clock— No walk before breakfast— I received a friendly Letter from my friend Richard Rush dated at Sydenham the 11th. instt. reminding me of my omission to acknowledge the receipt of his second volume concerning his Mission as Minister to Great Britain from 1817. to 1825—which I received from him last July—also a Letter from Aaron Gibbs dated Chicago Illinois 9. October 1845—asking for an Autograph— Received also from the
Revd. Andrew. P. Peabody a Copy of his Oration delivered before the Phi Beta Kappa Society of Harvard University on the 28. August last, upon the connection between Science and Religion which I heard and with which I was well pleased— Meeting of the Supervisors of the Adams Temple and School Fund at 12. o’clock. Present Thomas Greenleaf President Charles F. Adams Secretary, Josiah Quincy, George W. Beal. John Q. Adams— I offered a Resolution, which was adopted providing for standing Annual Meeting of the Corporation, in the Selectmens room of the Town Hall on the first Wednesday of September of every year, and another Resolution for the appointment of a Committee of three members to take into consideration the expediency of taking measures for the immediate erection of the School House proposed by the donations of my Father to the town of Quincy and to report thereon to the Board.— The Committee appointed consist of Josiah Quincy, C. F. Adams, and the President, Thomas Greenleaf This Resolution was adopted and another that the Committee be authorised to call a Meeting of the Supervisors to consider the subject whenever they shall see fit— It was also resolved that the Standing Committee on the subject of Leases for dwelling Houses be directed not to Lease any at a rate less than 12. dolls per annum for half acre and any of the Lots on the Hancock Lot at a rate less than 50. dolls a year— After the Meeting adjourned the Members of the Board remained to dinner together with the Revd. Mr. Lunt, and my Son’s family— While we were at dinner, I had a visit from Mr. Granville Harcourt-Vernon—an English gentleman who brought a Letter of introduction from my friend Christopher Hughes of Baltimore and another visit from the Revd. Mr. Williston, with his daughter, and Mr. and Mrs Tracy all from the Northern part of the State of Pennsylvania I went this morning with my Son and viewed the strip of land of which I executed a Deed to Mr.Emmons— Its object was merely to square off a boundary line of my Land with that upon which he is building his new House in amount to thirteen rods for which he gives 75. dolls the acknowledgment was taken by George W. Beal— My Son and his wife spent the evening with us—

Rose at five o’clock, white frost, clear sky—fair Autumnal weather— I received a Letter from Thomas Foulke, Jas. N. Mc.Elligotte—Leonard Hazeltine and N. J. O’Donnell—a Committee of the Teachers Institute, of the City of New-York, dated the 13 instt. inviting me to deliver a Lecture on some topic relative to the profession of a Teacher before that body on my way to Washington for the ensuing Session of Congress— I answered the Letters of John Eden, of Northampton
and enclosed an Autograph requested by him for a Literary friend in England, also a Letter from the Committee of the Citizens of Bristol, R.I requesting me to deliver a Lecture which I declined on account of the state of my health and a Letter from Richard Rush in which I acknowledged the receipt some weeks since of his second Volume, upon his Mission to England during the Administration of James Munroe— These three Letters I took to the Post Office and on my return home called on Mrs. Charles F. Adams, who is to remove with her family to Boston—for the Winter to-morrow— She took Tea and spent the evening here—

Rose at five o’clock. Frosty, but fair morning— Fahrenheit’s thermometer outside of the door at the Freezing point at sunrise After breakfast I walked up and deposited in the Stone Bank the check of Mr. George W. Beal for 120. dolls. 75. of which are for the strip of land conveyed to Mr. Emmons and 45. for the Pew No 16. in the Gallery of the Stone Temple sold to Mr. George T. Bigelow— I settled some small accounts with the Post-master Daniel French— On returning home, I stopt at my Son’s House and took leave of his Wife— They removed this day to Boston for the Winter— The Steamer Cambria sailed yesterday from Boston for Liverpool— Mr. Samuel T. Armstrong and his wife and Mrs. Fanny Kemble Butler go as passengers in her— I received this morning from the Author a Discourse Commemorative of the Life and Character of the late Joseph Story, an associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States and Dane Professor of Law in Harvard University, delivered 18. September 1845. at the request of the Corporation of the University and the members of the Law School by Simon Greenleaf. L.LD—Royal Professor of Law, at Harvard University— Answered several Letters from Christopher Hughes and one from Thomas Foulke, and others, Committee of the Teachers Institute of the City of New-York— Declining from ill health, to deliver the Lecture requested by them. I whiled away the afternoon from dinner to sunset in my Garden, Nursery, and Seminary—and went up the Hill, and saw the sunset from my Son’s solitary house at fourteen minutes past six o’clock in the line of the Western Urn and behind the brow of Mount Ararat. . . . Col William O McLee brought me a Letter of Introduction from Mr. Henry Clay— Dined with us and returned to Boston after dinner in the Stage— We missed very much my Son and his wife and daughter, at our evening Table— Charley Hays with us for the present— This was a remarkable day the Anniversary of Burgoyne’s capitulation 68. years ago, at Saratoga— The decisive event of the war for independence it has ever been to me, a day of Thanksgiving
and ought to be so, to the offspring of the people by whom that great deliverance was atchieved.

Rose before four and after five o’clock. After my usual mornings exercise so far as I am yet able to take it, I walked up to the Hill and saw the Sun rise in glory, from the eastern corner of my Son’s house—in line with the stem of English White Oak tree on the South side of the yard, at 15 minutes past Six o’clock— After breakfast John Kirk took up a Shagbark Walnut Tree from the Nursery, a Chesnut Oak Tree and a budded apple Tree, all seedlings of my own planting, to be sent to Mr. Andrew Jackson Downing of Newburg, New-York in performance of a promise made to him when he was here last Summer— I received a Letter, complimentary, from Mr. John. P. Burgett of Utica N.Y acknowledging his receipt of mine with a Copy of the Oration of the Life and character of Lafayette— Also a Letter from William B. Tappan of Boston enclosing a printed Circular entitled City Missions, being an Appeal to Evangelical Christians of all Denominations throughout Philadelphia and its vicinity— It is from the Board of Managers of the Evangelical association of Philadelphia and is a call for a contribution of ten-thousand dollars for means of Preaching the Gospel in the City of Philadelphia It contains the almost incredible assertion that it is believed there are more than 100.000. Souls in Philadelphia and its vicinity not regularly attached to any Place of Worship, and ready to perish for lack of vision— This is passing strange—but that the preaching of the Gospel in the City of Philadelphia should be suffered to depend upon contributions levyed in New-England is not only strange, but in my Judgment not deserving of encouragment I gave this day to my Grandaughter Mary Louisa Adams, my seal—of the bust of the Boylston Arms the Lion which I had engraved at Hirschberg in Silesia in August 1799— It is without the motto which I have since then adopted for it— Leo pro Deo— After taking to the Post Office the Letters written yesterday and this morning and several Copies of the Document the last Report of the Commissioner of the General Land Office I took a long walk on the embankment of the Boston and Old Colony Railroad from immediately behind the Grave Yard till I came to the level immediately North of my Houses at the foot of Penns Hill—from thence home. Immediately after dinner, Alfred R. Glover a young man desirous of obtaining a Warrant as a Cadet at the Military Academy at West Point came with Letters of Recommendation and Certificates as follows— 1.

list.item: 1. Letter to me—from E. P. Tileston—of Dorchester
2. Letter from Nathan. C. Martin, of Milton.
3. Letter from L. J. Marsh. Principle of the English and Classical High School, Dorchester
4. Certificate from E. J. Marsh. Principle of Milton Academy—
5. From. J. Mc.Kean. Churchill. Counsellor at Law. Boston—
7. Certificate from Richard Pyke. Minister of the 3d. Religious Society— Dorchester

div.p: I advised Mr. Glover, to address, a written application, for a Cadet’s Warrant, to William. L. Marcy Secretary of War—and send it to me and promised that I would forward it to-gether with these recommendations so that his name may be entered on the Books of the War Department as a Candidate for the Warrant— He asked me what prospect I thought there was of his success— I said I could not give him much encouragement as there were several applications of a prior date with strong recommendations— He said he would nevertheless send me the application— I rode this afternoon with Mrs. John Adams, Miss Cutts and Mary Louisa over Milton bridge and round in Dorchester returning by the way of Milton again— On our return home we found Mr. James H. Foster and his daughter Elizabeth who staid but a few minutes and returned to Boston— Reading in the evening in Frederika Bremers. Neighbors—

Rose at three—and at five— Saw the sun rise from my Sons House at 6.17. The Revd. Joseph Henry Allen minister at the 3d. Parish in Roxbury. Jamica Plains, preached by exchange with Mr. Lunt. His morning text was Mathew 6.19. “Lay not up for yourselves treasures upon earth where Moth and rust doth corrupt and where thieves break through and steal”—and his afternoon text was James 2.22— “Seest thou how faith wrought with his works and by works was faith made perfect”— Mr Allen dined with us and reminded me that yesterday was two years since I attended as a Delegate from the Church at Quincy at his Ordination— He is a young man of respectable talents educated at the theological School connected with Harvard University and preaches the doctrines prevailing in that Institution— The Steamship Hibernia arrived this morning from Liverpool, which she left on the fourth of this month with 107. passengers, 9 of whom were left at Halifax We made further progress this evening in reading Miss Bremers Neighbours—

Rose at three and at five o’clock. I received a Letter dated 16. instt. from the Revd. Dr. Nicholas Murray at Elizabethtown New Jersey, expressing the deepest sorrow at receiving the communication from me of my inability to attend at their ceremony on the 24th. of next Month.— He still urges my attendance if it be possible—which I believe it will not be— Also a Letter from Henry B. Dawson of New York requesting my Autograph and others for a Society of young men in that City and also a scrap for the Album of a Lady by his side—
Bigelow Dr Jacob.

I came into Boston this morning at the invitation of my son, and his wife to spend a week or more with them— Louisa C. Smith and Mary E. E. Cutts came in with me. Miss Cutts, to spend some days with her friend Mrs Richard C. Derby and Miss Smith to return this evening to Quincy. The ladies alighted at Mr James H. Foster’s, and I came to my son’s house No 57. Mt Vernon St. Miss Cutts dined with us there; I called before dinner at Mr Foster’s and also at Dr Bigelow’s house who not being at home I requested he would call in the Evening to see me at my son’s house. After dinner I took a walk of an hour, and spent the evening with my son and his wife. Dr Bigelow came and I stated to him the present condition of my health. For which, He prescribed, a continuance, of the regimen which he had advised when I last saw him, at his own house.

My Granddaughter Louisa Catharine lends me her hand to write. I slept this morning till near five o’clock, I then rose, and performed my ritual lustrations, ablutions and frictions. I took a long walk after breakfast in the morning, and another after dinner. I called at Harding’s gallery in school St. and saw Mr Healy who has returned from Marshfield where he has been painting a portrait of Mr Daniel Webster. Mr Du Bourjal was not there. Mr Healy requested me to give him another sitting positively the last to finish my portrait which I promised to do at 11 o’clock next thursday morning. I met in a bookseller’s shop Mr Isaac P. Davis who told me that his brother the Judge was sick, confined to his bed. I next went to Amory hall and saw Mr King the Sculptor and the cast of my bust. He told me that he intended to make a cameo from it for himself: he said also that he had received four orders for copies of the bust. And that every person who had seen it pronounced it an excellent likeness. In walking to the south part of the city I found an entire new street called Dover St. many of the houses of which are not yet finished. Near there I met Mr
Alexander H. Everett and his wife walking. He was appointed during the last session of congress, commissioner of the United States to China. with a salary of five thousand dollars a year and no outfit— I used all the influence in my power that he should have the rank and compensation of an envoy extraordinary and minister plenipotentiary; to which the house of representatives agreed but which the senate refused to sanction reducing the rank to that of a simple commissioner and the salary to five thousand dollars— He embarked in may last with his wife at New York, but on his way was taken ill and at Rio Janeiro found himself so much indisposed that by the advice of his physicians instead of proceeding to China returned to this country and arrived here about a fortnight since. He had still some expectation of recovering his health sufficiently to go out again upon his mission. Dr Frothingham spent part of the evening with us at my son’s house.

Rose at five o’clock, after a sound night’s sleep— Fuller came in with the carriage early this morning supposing that we were to go out to Milton to Mr Safford the justice’s court. Miss Cutts called here after Breakfast. Morning visit from Josiah Quincy late president of Harvard University. He told me that Mr Edward Everett went with him yesterday to the autumnal exhibition at Cambridge, and visited the several establishments there including the observatory. It is the intention of the corporation to elect Mr Edward Everett as president of the University, but the usage being in that body to ascertain before the election whether the person whom they intend to choose will accept the appointment they are waiting for the determination of Mr Everett before proceeding to elect him. I took morning and afternoon long walks called upon Mr Henry Gassett and conversed with him upon the proposed republication of my letters upon freemasonry. He lent me a volume of pamphlets upon that subject. I also visited the late Judge, John Davis; who is recovering from the illness which confined him yesterday to his bed. Mr and Mrs Edward Everett spent part of the
evening here. They were about five years in Europe, two in Italy, and three in England.

I woke this morning just before the dawn at 1/2 past four o’clock. My son went out to Quincy and returned after dinner. Miss Cutts called soon after breakfast. I gave another last sitting to Mr Healy, and Mr Du Bourjal for my portrait. I believe Mr Healy’s picture is the strongest likeness of me that ever was painted, and I told him that I hoped it was the last portrait that ever would be painted of me. Mr Weston was there during part of the sitting and he too is a painter, and a man of taste and intelligence. Mr Healy requested that any of my friends who wished to see my portrait should come on Saturday morning. His portraits of General Andrew Jackson and Mr Clay painted for Louis Phillippe, King of the French, and that of Colonel Richard M. Johnson are all there and all incomparable likenesses. Mrs Richard C. Derby and Miss Cutts were here this afternoon. My son brought me from Quincy a letter from Daniel Mallery, agent of the union school of inebriates at Philadelphia—containing his report of the Union school and soliciting of me to deliver a lecture for their benefit and a small donation. Also a letter from W. G. E. Agnew and others. a committee of the board of managers of the Methodist Episcopal church of the city and county of Philadelphia, requesting me to deliver a lecture for their benefit, also a letter from John Eden of Northampton, with quotations from Milton and Juvenal. I wrote a letter to the Secretary of War enclosing the application of Alfred R. Glover of Milton for a warrant of cadet at West-Point and seven letters and certificates recommendatory of him—

Besides the usual long walks of morning and afternoon with the help of Mrs Charles I answered the letters of Daniel Mallery agent for the Union school for the children of Inebriates at Philadelphia, and declined both the requests to deliver a lecture and to contribute a donation for the benefit of that Institution, not that I disapprove of its object but first because I am unable to deliver a
lecture anywhere and secondly because I think the City of Philadelphia should charge itself with the education of the children of its own drunkards. I answered also the letter of W. G. E. Agnew and others of the Home missionary Society of the Methodist Episcopal church of the City & County of Philadelphia and declined to deliver a lecture for their benefit. In my morning walk I met Miss Eliza Susan Quincy who invited me to pass this evening at her father’s house which I did. It was a family party with two or three friends among whom was Mr Metcalfe of Natchez in the state of Mississippi. My son and Mrs Charles spent the evening at their neighbor Mr Parker’s. My son went with me in Mr Quincy’s and came there and led me home.

The eighty first anniversary of my fathers marriage. Morning visit from Mr B. W. Crowninshield, also from Mrs. Richard C. Derby and Miss Cutts, with whom and Mrs Charles I went to see Mr Healy’s portraits, at Harding’s Gallery in School St. and after that to see Mr King’s bust of Me at Amory hall— After which I went with Mrs Derby to her house. Mr Derby had a large collection of paintings colored engravings and beautiful marble statues. On returning home I found at the door of My Son’s house Mrs Freeman, widow of the late Lieutenant Colonel Freeman of the marine corps. She is in great affliction and has a claim of upon the Government of the United States for Justice so far as it can be rendered to her late husband. She has made application to the President of the United States and the Secretary of the Navy, Mr George Bancroft who has informed her that the Executive Government however they may sympathise with her case have no power to afford her relief. She asked my advice what she should do. I recommended that she should address a memorial to Congress stating all the facts of the injustice done to her husband and soliciting an act for her relief— That she should address a copy of the memorial
to each of the two houses of Congress and promised to present to the house of Representatives the one addressed to that body. Towards evening with my son and three of his children, I visited the Chinese Museum at the old Marlboro’ Chapel in Washington St. after which I went and took tea and spent the evening at Dr. Frothingham’s. We examined the passage in Juvenal used in Mr John Eden’s letter. Dr Frothingham accompanied me home, and we met on the way my son who was coming for me.

Heard Dr Frothingham at the first Congregational church In Chauncey Place. His morning text was Numbers 13,32. “And they brought up an evil report of the land which they had searched, unto the children of Israel, saying the land through which we have gone to search it is a land that eateth up the inhabitants thereof, and all the people that we saw in it are men of a great stature. 33. and there we saw the giants the sons of Anak which come of the giants and we were in our own sight as Grasshoppers and so we were in their sight.” His afternoon text was Amos 5.13 “Therefore the prudent shall keep silence in that that time for it is an evil time.” In the evening with my Granddaughter Louisa Catharine I heard the Oratorio of “Samson,” performed by the Handel and Hayden Society at the Melodeon with which I was very much pleased.

Morning visits to Mr George Ticknor, and Mr Francis C. Gray neither of whom has the Variorum edition of Juvenal but both have the Edition of Ruperte in which the reading is “Nullum numen habes.” Miss Cutts dined with us. Mrs Freeman’s son Rufus Green Amory Freeman brought me a copy of her memorial to Congress, which she is to send me with sundry . . .ments to be presented to the house of Representatives. Mrs Charles went to Cambridge this afternoon to visit her sister Mrs Edward Brooks but returned early this evening
which we spent at Mr. Josiah Quincy’s Junr. with a family party and a few friends— These evening parties are customary in this City, held weekly at the Houses of the several branches of the family alternately once a week during the Winter— There was one whist table made up with some difficulty and in which I declined to take a hand preferring to pass the time in conversation— There was no music—

I returned a visit of Mr. B. W. Crowninshield but he was not at home, nor was the late Judge John Davis so recently confined to his house by severe cold— I met in the Street Captn. Charles Wilkes recently from Washington and convalescent from chills and fevers—he told me that in three or four days he should start for Washington, and said he should be very glad to go in company with my wife and family, who propose to go next Monday— I met also Mr. Joseph Grinnell of New Bedford who told me he expected Mrs Grinnell here this evening, and that they intend to go to Washington to be there by the Saturday before the Meeting of Congress on the first day of December— My wife with Mrs. John Adams and her daughter Mary Louisa came to Boston and dined at my Sons and I came out with them to Quincy after dinner— We had barely alighted from the Carriage when a person by the name of John Wilson came with a claim against the Estate of Dr. Boylston the Grandson of the late Ward Nicholas Boylston who lived and died at Charleston South Carolina— The Claim was for clothing furnished him while he was a student at Cambridge in 1812 or 1813— It was originally a claim against Mr Ward N. Boylston but in March 1824. Mr Wilson took in satisfaction of that claim several promissory notes of Dr. Boylston himself dated at Charleston where he then resided and payable at distant terms from six months I think to three years—and of these notes Mr. Wilson now demands payment—for that purpose he applied to the late Mrs. Alicia Boylston while she lived and to Captain Nathaniel Curtis as Co-executors with me of Mr. Ward N. Boylstons Will— They informed him that they had no funds from which they could undertake to make the payment— I told him I supposed I could give him no other answer, but that I would consult with Mr. Curtis my surviving Co-executor and if we should be possessed of any fund from which we can legally make the payment I shall cheerfully consent to make it—he promised to call some day next week at my Sons Office No. 23. Court Street Boston for a final answer— Later in the evening Mr. Jonathan Wild of Randolph called on me concerning a claim to a Pension of his Mother as the Widow of his Father, who was a Pensioner for Military Services during the war of the Revolution— He had no documents with him but promised to procure such as he can obtain and to produce them to me here or at my Sons Office in Boston in the course of a fortnight— I returned from Boston after a visit of eight days to my Son and daughter there passed very agreeably and with temporary apparent improvement of my health but merely temporary and apparent—all my complaints being too deeply seated to be ever removed—
29. IV.15. Wednesday. Sun rose 6.29. Set 5—

I awoke a quarter before and rose a quarter after four— After dressing and its usual exercise I walked up the hill to see the Sun rise from the Eastern corner of my Sons house but a thick cloud on the borders of the horizon intercepted the sight of the Sun, the sky above was however clear and I had seen the Great-Bear perpendicular tail downwards and Arcturus and the Moon rising about the same time close upon five oclock— Immediately after breakfast Mr. Charles Ewer of Braintree called on me to ask my final determination upon the invitation to me of the three Towns of Braintree Quincy, and Randolph to write for publication the History of Braintree— This invitation was given about four years since—and I promised to undertake it if my health and leisure should ever permit— Some weeks since Mr. Ewer called upon me to remind me of this promise and I then informed him that in all probability I should not be able to perform it— I now repeated it the same as my final answer having no hope of ever being enabled to execute the task— Mr. Ewer expressed a willingness for himself and other inhabitants of Braintree carefully to collect all the documents and other materials which may be necessary for the composition of the work—but I told him that I had renounced the hope of ever being able to perform it— I answered the letter from Brantz Mayer which accompanied the Journal of Charles Carroll of Carrollton during his visit to Canada in 1776— My Son came out from Boston and dined with us and returned after dinner— A person by the name of Allen called this Afternoon, but I was walking out and did not see him— I found on reaching home last evening, a letter from Mr. James H. Hackett dated Tremont House Boston 23d. instt. with his Manuscript Common-place book, containing humourous remarks upon Shakespear’s Plays and upon several of the principal performers of the part of Hamlet—his correspondence with me upon that subject is pasted in printed slips in this Volume, and his Letter requests a spare copy if I have one of my remarks heretofore published upon the Tragedy of Othello— His Common place book furnished us amusement for this evenings reading—

div.dateline: Thursday 30th. of October 1845. Quincy, Boston, Quincy
div.p: 30. IV— V— New Moon this evening 6.59—

I went to Boston this morning with my wife and our first call was at Hardings Gallery School Street, where she saw Mr. Healys and Mr. Dubourjal’s Portraits of me—and was pleased with them both— She thinks that Mr. Healy the strongest likeness ever painted of me— Those of Genl. Jackson and Mr. Clay painted for King Louis Phillippe and that of Coll. Richard M. Johnson are all admirable, perhaps never been so elaborately finished as mine— I asked Mr. Healy if he would have any objection to my having a copper plate engraving of it before he takes it away to France—he said it was his intention to obtain the permission of the King to have copper plate engravings made of the three Portraits ordered by him—
I called at Little and Browns Booksellers shop and enquired for the Book which I had bespoken for Mr. Alexander Sheldon of Randolph Cataraugus County New York—which he requested of one by his Letter of the 8th. of September last, but they told me that the book was at the binders and would not be finished till next Sunday— I met in the Shop Dr. Convers Francis, Ex-President Josiah Quincy, and the Revd. George Putnam of Roxbury, who gave me a slip, containing the following extract from the Records of his Church— Rebecca daughter of Thos. & Mary Boylston born Septr. 15th. 1685— Benjamin Boylston of Brookline & Elizabeth Sumner of Roxbury married Novr. 30th. 1727—
Robert Boylston &March 29. 1750—

These he said were all the entries of the name of Boylston that he had found in the Book— I met in the Street the Revd. Dr. John Codman of Dorchester recently returned from a visit to England and Scotland who thanked me for having procured for him last Spring a Passport from the Department of State— I attended at twelve oclock the monthly meeting of the Massachusetts Historical Society—the President Mr. James Savage was in the chair, but the Meeting was very thin and no business of any consequence transacted— I made my apology for the non performance of my promise, made at the last meeting in May to prepare for delivery, a Historical Memoir upon the Patent Office of the United States, which the state of my health has disabled me from completing— I stated my doubts whether I should ever be able to complete it—but that I had not entirely given up that hope, or at least that of finishing, and presenting it to the Society, even if I should not be enabled to deliver it as a discourse at a public Meeting— From the Society’s rooms I went to my Sons house where I found my wife—we dined there and returned after dinner to Quincy—

31. II— III— IV— V— I mark the hours at which I heard the clock strike in the night and at the last of which I arose from bed— I received this morning a letter from Mr Henry Gassett dated at Boston yesterday, and enclosing a subscription list for the republication of my writings on the subject of Free Masonry— These proposals were issued in August last and the subscription for them amounts to six hundred and seventy five dollars, for distributing gratuitously the whole Edition— The application to me for this republication was made first on the 30th. of September 1844. by Henry Gassett, George Odiorne, John D. Williams, and Daniel Weld, see my Journal of that date.— I promised them to prepare a preface, to this republication, if possible in the course of the then next Summer, which I have however not been able to perform— They have repeatedly renewed the application and Mr. Gassett has furnished me with all the books and papers necessary for the execution of the task— Meanwhile my disability has been increasing from day to day, and now I am indebted to my daughter Mrs. John Adams for writing even this record of my Diary—
Last week while I was in Boston Messrs. Gassett, Odiorne, Williams & Weld, came out again to remind me of my promise to prepare this Preface—and I am reminded of it again by the letter and copy of the proposals received this morning from Mr. Gassett— I received also a Letter from Augustus Harris of Coldbrook, Coos County New Hampshire of the 20th. of October asking for Documents to prevent the Election of John Woodbury as a member of Congress from that State, because he is in favor of the Annexation of Texas— This comes a day too late— Also a letter from Thomas G. Whittemore, who married the daughter of my Cousin Susanna Adams asking for an Autograph of my Father—the letter is dated at Cambridge yesterday— He is the Post Master there— I answered the letter of Mr Gassett, and despatched it with a letter to Commodore Jesse D. Elliott informing him of the refusal of the Historical Society of Rhode Island to receive his Medal struck in honor of J. Finnemore Cooper and of the correspondence between John Howland President of that Society and me relating to this subject— This afternoon with my wife and daughter I rode round the Braintree Meeting House square, and we amused the evening with Mr. Hacketts Manuscript notes upon Shakespeare—
